thread.title: Juncker warns on Euro climate refugees without Paris deal
thread.title_full: Juncker warns on Euro climate refugees without Paris deal

author: David Twomey
title: Juncker warns on Euro climate refugees without Paris deal
text:
Tweet 
The European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has becomes latest to use the current refugee crisis to underscore need for urgent action on climate change. 
Mr Juncker has called for the world to sign an ambitious deal to tackle climate change this year, and warned rising temperatures could worsen the refugee crisis Europe is currently facing. 
In his State of the Union speech , Mr Juncker warned there was “no time to lose” in committing to a bold agreement at the United Nations climate change summit in December. 
He said the European Union should fight for an ambitious deal and should not be prepared to sign anything. 
With thousands of migrants entering Europe this summer from the Middle East, sparking a crisis between member states over where they will be able to reside, Mr Juncker warned that the future refugees would come to Europe to escape the worst impacts of climate change. 
“We are tackling the root causes of the next migration wave in the coming decades,” he said. 
“Because tomorrow morning we will have climate refugees and we should not be surprised or astonished if the first climate refugees are coming to Europe. 
“We have to act now because we don’t have time to lose and that’s why I want the EU and its member states to be as ambitious as possible on the way to Paris.” 
Mr Juncker is the latest politician to use the migrant crisis to underline the need for swift action on climate change. 
Earlier this week French President Francois Hollande warned that climate change would intensify the migrant crisis facing Europe. 
“We won’t have hundreds of thousands of refugees in the next 20 or 30 years, but millions,” he told a press conference on Monday. 
Mr Juncker also said that climate change and scarcity of natural resources were changing the sources of conflict. 
“The control over a dam or a lake can be more strategic than an oil refinery,” he added. 
He said Energy Commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete was currently in Papua New Guinea discussing the plans for Paris with the leaders of the Pacific Islands Forum. 
“If corrective action is not taken to tackle climate change, the tide will rise and those islands will be the proverbial canary in the coalmine.”
